description: From ambi- +‎ Latin dexter (“right", "skillful”) + -ous (as if both hands are like the right hand, which is the stronger hand in most people).

adjectives.description: ambidextrous (comparative more ambidextrous, superlative most ambidextrous)

entries.meaning: Having equal ability in both hands; in particular, able to write equally well with both hands.
Equally usable by left-handed and right-handed people (as a tool or instrument).
(archaic) Practising or siding with both parties.
Exceptionally skillful; adept in more than one medium, genre, style, etc.
examples: Michelangelo was a very ambidextrous artist, producing sculptures and frescoes with equal ability.
